prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for yelling at someone else’s kid
Yesterday was Christmas and all of my family was in my parents house with their kids. A little background I have a 7yr son who has mild autism which makes it a little hard for him to fit in with the other kids. Ok back to the story, at one point in the day my cousin’s daughter 13yr was messing with my son by taking his toys that my mother keeps in the house for him and hiding them from him which made him upset. And later on she started making me made by telling my sister’s kids that my son was a, ”Retard.” Then came to me nudged me and said, “Is your son a retard so I snapped and yelled at this kid, “YOU CAN’T CALL MY SON A RETARD!” All of my family members of course heard me, and the girl started crying. Her mom get mad at me for, “Using that language around her.” And I was blowing up inside so much that I couldn’t stay so I grabbed my son and husband and walked out with every watching.

It feels good writing this down and I just want a little feedback on if that was the write thing to do which I know it wasn’t.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The other child's actions were clearly inappropriate—hiding toys and using a derogatory term. The term "retard" is offensive and hurtful, especially when said to a child with autism. The author's reaction was to yell, which caused the other child to cry and the mother to be upset.

Now, the question is whether the author is in the wrong. On one hand, defending their child from bullying and harmful language is understandable. On the other hand, yelling, even if in anger, might not be the most constructive response. However, given the circumstances—another child using a derogatory term and the author's emotional state—it's a reaction born out of parental instinct. The author left the situation, which might have been a way to de-escalate further.

But the user initially thought the author is in the wrong, but maybe that's because of the yelling.
